predictions.text: The U.S. government (Treasury/OFAC, DHS/Coast Guard, or another federal agency) will publish an official notice (press release or Federal Register) announcing new enforcement guidance, interdiction authority, or expanded sanctions specifically targeting Venezuelan crude/oil-product maritime shipments by 2026-01-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if by the deadline there is an official U.S. government publication (Treasury/OFAC press release, DHS/USCG statement, or Federal Register notice) that explicitly announces new or expanded enforcement/sanctions measures aimed at Venezuelan oil shipping (tankers, maritime transport, insurers, or facilitators).
evidence: Recent reporting indicates the U.S. president ordered a blockade of sanctioned Venezuelan oil tankers and labeled Venezuela a terrorist regime, which commonly precedes formal enforcement or sanctions actions.
OFAC and related agencies frequently operationalize new policy stances via press releases, FAQs, or Federal Register actions.
monitoring_signals: U.S. Treasury/OFAC press releases and FAQs mentioning Venezuela, PDVSA, tankers, shipping, or insurers
Federal Register notices referencing Venezuela sanctions, maritime enforcement, or interdiction rules
DHS/USCG advisories (MARAD, MSIBs) referencing Venezuela or sanctions compliance
predictions.rationale: High-profile policy signaling on Venezuelan oil shipping often leads to formal, citable guidance or sanctions/enforcement notices within weeks.

predictions.text: At least one major marine insurer (e.g., NorthStandard, Gard, UK P&I Club) or top-tier tanker operator (e.g., Frontline, Euronav, Teekay, Angelicoussis group entity) will publicly announce a suspension/restriction of coverage or carriage specifically for Venezuela-related crude/oil-product voyages due to U.S. enforcement risk by 2026-02-28 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a named major P&I club/insurer or a top-tier publicly visible tanker operator issues a public statement, circular, or filing explicitly restricting or suspending Venezuela-related voyages/coverage citing U.S. sanctions/enforcement risk.
evidence: Reported escalation in U.S. posture toward Venezuelan oil tankers increases compliance risk for shippers and insurers.
Shipping/insurance firms commonly issue compliance circulars rapidly when sanctions enforcement tightens.
monitoring_signals: P&I club circulars and compliance advisories referencing Venezuela
Operator press releases, investor calls, or filings referencing Venezuela exposure changes
Shipping intelligence reports noting insurance coverage withdrawals on Venezuela routes
predictions.rationale: Even limited U.S. enforcement escalation can trigger risk-avoidance behavior among insurers/operators active in sanctioned or high-risk trades.

predictions.text: NYMEX WTI crude oil front-month futures will settle at or below $60.00 per barrel on at least one trading day by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the official settlement price of the NYMEX WTI (CL) front-month contract is <= 60.00 USD/bbl on any trading day on or before the deadline.
evidence: Recent news reports indicate crude prices have fallen to the lowest since early 2021 on surplus concerns.
A surplus narrative can generate downside tail events even if the central path is higher.
monitoring_signals: Daily NYMEX CL front-month settlement prices
EIA weekly inventory/production data and OPEC+ policy headlines
Global demand indicators (PMIs, freight, refining margins)
predictions.rationale: With crude already weak on surplus expectations, a further risk-off or inventory shock could plausibly push WTI through $60 at least once.

predictions.text: A U.S. federal court will issue a temporary restraining order (TRO) or preliminary injunction that blocks or pauses enforcement of at least one material part of the expanded U.S. travel restrictions affecting newly added countries by 2026-02-15 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a federal district court or appellate court issues a TRO or preliminary injunction (order on the docket) that explicitly blocks/pauses enforcement of at least one substantive provision of the newly expanded travel restrictions for at least one affected country/class of travelers.
evidence: Recent expansion of travel restrictions to many countries increases the likelihood of rapid litigation by states, NGOs, and affected individuals.
Prior large-scale travel restrictions have historically faced immediate court challenges and interim relief requests.
monitoring_signals: PACER filings and major civil-liberties litigation announcements
DOJ court filings and emergency motions
Implementation guidance from DHS/State that signals disputed provisions
predictions.rationale: Broad, fast-moving travel restrictions frequently prompt swift lawsuits where TROs/PI orders are plausible, even if later narrowed or stayed.

predictions.text: Tesla will update consumer-facing Autopilot/FSD marketing language (website purchase flow or official product page) to remove or materially qualify at least one capability claim cited in the California deceptive-marketing ruling, by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if Tesla changes its official Autopilot/FSD web pages or purchasing UI text in a way that removes or adds prominent qualifying language to a capability claim referenced in the ruling (as evidenced by archived page diffs/screenshots or reputable reporting citing the change).
evidence: A California judge found Tesla engaged in deceptive Autopilot/FSD marketing, raising incentive to mitigate legal/regulatory exposure.
Companies commonly respond to adverse rulings with marketing copy revisions rather than immediate product changes.
monitoring_signals: Tesla Autopilot/FSD product pages (archived diffs, Wayback, change trackers)
Tesla legal disclosures in 10-K/10-Q and regulator communications
Media reports on Tesla marketing and FSD labeling updates
predictions.rationale: Marketing language is a relatively low-cost lever for Tesla to reduce litigation risk following an adverse deceptive-marketing finding.

predictions.text: Waymo will publicly confirm closing a new external funding round with disclosed proceeds of at least $10.0B by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if Waymo/Alphabet or credible financial reporting confirms a closed financing round for Waymo with disclosed total new capital raised >= $10.0B (equity and/or primary capital), by the deadline.
evidence: Recent reporting indicates Waymo is in talks to raise $15B, implying both need and investor interest.
Robotaxi scaling requires heavy capital for fleet, operations, and compute.
monitoring_signals: Waymo/Alphabet press releases and SEC filings (if material)
Credible outlet reporting confirming round close and size (e.g., WSJ, Bloomberg, CNBC)
Secondary signals: hiring acceleration, fleet expansion announcements, new market launches
predictions.rationale: If negotiations are real and strategic investors remain interested, a large round could close within 6 months—though sizing makes it uncertain.

predictions.text: Databricks will publicly file an S-1 (or confidentially submit a draft registration statement that it publicly acknowledges) for a U.S. IPO by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if Databricks (1) publicly files an S-1 with the SEC, or (2) publicly announces it has confidentially submitted a draft registration statement for an IPO, by the deadline.
evidence: Databricks recently raised $4B at a very high valuation, often a precursor to IPO readiness but not always immediate.
AI/data-platform leaders face strong public-market narratives when IPO windows reopen.
monitoring_signals: SEC EDGAR for Databricks filings
Company statements about IPO readiness/auditor changes/governance upgrades
IPO market conditions (volatility, tech IPO performance)
predictions.rationale: A major late-stage raise can bridge to an IPO; timing depends on market window and internal readiness, making this plausible but not likely.

predictions.text: The DEA will publish a final rule in the Federal Register rescheduling marijuana to Schedule III by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the Federal Register publishes a DEA final rule that reschedules marijuana to Schedule III on or before the deadline.
evidence: Recent reporting indicates strong political consideration of cannabis rescheduling, increasing the chance of accelerated administrative action.
Final rules typically follow proposed rules with variable but sometimes rapid timelines under political priority.
monitoring_signals: Federal Register search for DEA/cannabis/marijuana scheduling entries
DOJ/DEA press releases and OMB/OIRA regulatory agenda updates
Statements from HHS/DEA leadership or congressional oversight signals
predictions.rationale: Same outcome as prior forecast but with a shorter deadline reflecting increased political salience; still uncertain due to administrative and legal process risk.

predictions.text: The U.S. Unemployment Rate (seasonally adjusted) for February 2026 will print at or above 4.8%.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the BLS Employment Situation release for February 2026 reports U-3 unemployment rate (seasonally adjusted) >= 4.8%.
evidence: Recent jobs report showed unemployment at 4.6% with weak payroll growth, consistent with gradual labor-market softening.
Labor-market turning points can push unemployment up in discrete steps.
monitoring_signals: Weekly initial claims trend and continuing claims
Monthly payroll diffusion and hours worked
Business surveys (ISM employment components) and layoff announcements
predictions.rationale: Starting from 4.6%, a modest deterioration could reach 4.8% by February, but the labor market could also stabilize, keeping odds below 50%.

predictions.text: At the March 2026 FOMC meeting, the Federal Reserve will cut the federal funds target range by at least 25 basis points versus its level immediately before the meeting.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the FOMC announcement for the March 2026 meeting shows the target range upper bound reduced by >= 0.25 percentage points relative to the pre-meeting target range.
evidence: Recent payroll growth appears weak and unemployment is drifting higher, increasing the probability of further easing after any earlier move.
However, inflation uncertainty can delay cuts even amid softer activity.
monitoring_signals: Fed communication (speeches, SEP updates if applicable) and market-implied path (OIS/FF futures)
Inflation prints (CPI/PCE) and labor-market cooling indicators
Financial conditions indices and credit spreads
predictions.rationale: Softening labor data raises easing odds, but inflation and policy caution keep the probability under 50% for a specific meeting.
